page.title: 16FLORA OF THE LUGG FLATS
page.content: The Lugg Flats are flooded whenever the River Lugg rises above a certain level and this flooding increases the value of the grazing. The area is held "in common" from Lammas to Candlemas. For the rest of the year owners can take hay crops from their individual plots which are marked with stones. The flora of the Flats is unique. To save the Snakes Head fritillaries the Nature Trust has become one of the Lugg Flats Commoners and the rare Ophioglossum Fern has recently been rediscovered there. Perennial pools in water courses passing under the main road contain an interesting Flora including Water Dropworts, Flowering Rush, Arrowhead and Water Plantain. The variety of Flora in the area has led it to be designated as an "Area of Special Scientific Interest".
